tn.text: This is a desert region on the eastern border of Egypt. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: sent his men and they took Sarah
tn.text: "made his men go get Sarah and bring her to him"
"God appeared to Abimelech"
Here the word "behold" adds emphasis to what follows. "Listen to me" (UDB)
This is a strong way of saying the king will die. AT: "you will certainly die soon" or "I will kill you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"a married woman"
This word is used here to mark a change from the story to information about Abimelech. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])

tn.ref: Abimelech had not come near her
tn.text: This is a polite way of saying he did not have sex with her. AT: "Abimelech had not slept with Sarah" or "Abimelech had not touched Sarah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
Here "nation" stands for the people. Abimelech is worried that God will punish not only him, but his people also. AT: "even a people who are innocent" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Did he not himself say to me, 'She is my sister?' Even she herself said, 'He is my brother'
tn.text: This has quotations within a quotation. They can be stated as indirect quotations. AT: "Did he himself not tell me that she is his sister? Even she herself told me that he is her brother" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotesinquotes]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])

tn.ref: Did he not himself say to me, 'She is my sister?'
tn.text: Abimelech used this rhetorical question to remind God of something God already knew. This can be translated as a statement. AT: "Abraham himself told me 'She is my sister.'" or "Abraham said that she is his sister." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Did he not himself say ... Even she herself
tn.text: The words "he himself" and "she herself" are used for emphasis to bring attention to Abraham and Sarah and to blame them for what happened. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_rpronouns]])

tn.ref: I have done this in the integrity of my heart and the innocence of my hands
tn.text: Here "heart" stands for his thoughts or intentions. Also "hands" stands for his actions. AT: "I have done this with good intentions and actions" or "I have done this with no evil thoughts or actions" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"God said to Abimelech"

tn.ref: in the integrity of your heart you did this
tn.text: Here "heart" stands for his thoughts or intentions. AT: "you did this with good intentions" or "you did this without evil intentions" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This is a euphemism for having sex with Sarah. AT: "to sleep with her" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
"Abraham's wife"
"I will let you live"
"all of your people"

tn.ref: He told all these things to them
tn.text: "He told them everything that God had told him"

tn.ref: What have you done to us?
tn.text: Abimelech used this rhetorical question to accuse Abraham. AT: "You have done something bad to us!" or "Look what you have done to us!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
The word "us" here is exclusive and does not include Abraham and Sarah. If your language uses an exclusive form of "we" or "us," use it here. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])

tn.ref: How have I sinned against you, that you have brought ... sin?
tn.text: Abimelech used this rhetorical question to remind Abraham that he had not sinned against Abraham. AT: "I have done nothing against you to cause you to bring ... sin." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: that you have brought on me and on my kingdom a great sin
tn.text: To cause someone to be guilty of sinning is spoken of as if "sin" was a thing  that could be placed on a person. AT: "that you should make me and my kingdom guilty of such a terrible sin" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here "kingdom" stands for the people. AT: "on the people of my kingdom" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: You have done to me that which ought not to be done
tn.text: "You should not have done this to me"

tn.ref: What prompted you to do this thing?
tn.text: "What caused you to do this?" or "Why did you do this?" What Abraham did can be stated explicitly. AT: "Why did you tell me that Sarah is your sister?" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: Because I thought, 'Surely there is no fear of God in this place, and they will kill me because of my wife.'
tn.text: This is a quotation within a quotation. It can be stated as an indirect quotation. AT: "Because I thought that since no one here fears God, someone may kill me so they can take my wife." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotesinquotes]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])

tn.ref: no fear of God in this place
tn.text: Here "place" refers to the people. AT: "no one here in Gerar fears God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This means to deeply respect God and show that respect by obeying him.

tn.ref: Besides, she is indeed my sister
tn.text: "Also, it is true that Sarah is my sister" or "Also, Sarah really is my sister"

tn.ref: the daughter of my father, but not the daughter of my mother
tn.text: "we have the same father, but we have different mothers"
Verse 13 is a continuation of Abraham's answer to Abimelech.
Here "house" stands for Abraham's family. AT: "my father and the rest of my family" or "my father's household" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: I said to her, 'You must show me this faithfulness as my wife: At every place where we go, say about me, "He is my brother."'
tn.text: This has quotations within quotations. They can be stated as indirect quotations. AT: "I said to Sarah that I wanted her to be faithful to me by telling people everywhere we go that I am her brother" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotesinquotes]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])
"Abimelech brought some" (UDB)
"Abimelech said to Abraham"
Here and in verse 16 the word "look" adds emphasis to what follows.
This is a way of saying "I make all of my land available to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"Live wherever you want"
"1,000" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: It is to cover any offense against you in the eyes of all that are with you
tn.text: Giving money to prove to others that Sarah is innocent is spoken of as if he is placing a cover over an offense so no one can see it. AT: "I am giving this to him, so that those who are with you will know that you have done nothing wrong" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here "eyes" stands for a person's thoughts or opinion. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: before everyone, you are completely made right
tn.text: The passive phrase "made right" can be stated in active form. AT: "everyone will know that you are innocent" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"totally unable to have children"
The full meaning can be stated explicitly. AT: "because Abimelech had taken Abraham's wife Sarah" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
